text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name ____________________________
Present Address ____________________________
Pioneer Address ____________________________
Year you came to Saskatchewan ________________

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 6

How many of these were bachelor's homes? 3

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? not often

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? any time

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? without any invitation

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? any time

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? yes

everybody was welcome.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

everybody was our big family - always welcome to meal

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? everybody went

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? occasionally

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Dances in the different homes

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? no
1. In the first few years how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's houses?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

What time of the day did you go? - In the morning and spend the day? or in the afternoon, etc.?

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly?

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "lock after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "teas" then, groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, have quilts, or other such activity?

Tell that you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the teas were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn, going from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a month, etc.?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc. if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

not much

9. When was your first community hall built? Community hall in 1917

What material was it made of? How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

Hall was used for all gatherings

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? Yes

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Euchre, Ring Poker

Was there card playing for a prize? No

What dances were popular? Square dances, Waltzes, Quadrilles, Polkas

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

No

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
2.

Tell what was made of the school house for community purposes, how much was used for other activities. (Include also the school, church, town, parish, etc., if you have not described them in the School Questionnaire.) Give dates.

How much of your school hall was rented around the school, and within the body of the district? Describe.

9.

When was your first community hall built? How large was it? How long did it last?

What material was it made of? Who built it - the community through special funds, the school authorities, etc.? How was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? In what part of the school was it located? Did you continue to use the local school house, or were you forced to make use of the hall for all gatherings etc.?

10.

When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter times at these parties?

11.

What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What names were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the house, or for community gatherings? Explain.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.?  

no ceremony

13. Was the chivaree known in your community?  

no
Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

The Grain Growers
Give the date and reason for it being organized.

Nov. 1912

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community?  

yes (new division)
Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

1912
Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?
nearly all
How many women belonged?  
How often did it meet? once a month
What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?
made quilts & raffled them

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district?  

They succeeded The Women's Grain Growers
When was it organized?
Approximately how many women belonged to it?
Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
12. What attempts at formality or "mannish" do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visiting cards, especially in parlor, etc.? 

13. Was the chivalry known in your community? 

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember. 

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember being organized in your community? 

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' Club in your community? 

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? 

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember being organized in your community? 

Give the date and reason for its being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' Club in your community? 

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged to it?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? 

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was founded, its size (number of members), its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

[Handwritten text]

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

Bazaars, suppers & Dances

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

[Handwritten text]

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? No

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? [Handwritten text] Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

Baseball, Tag, Parcheesy

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

[Handwritten text]
4. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1923.

5. What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

6. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

7. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? If so, who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

8. Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

9. Who provided the lanterns and the slides?

10. What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (skipping rope, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

22. What games did girls play in summer (skipping rope, play houses, etc.)?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

No. The grown ups

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

Lots of time

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

Rode horses, held or house made slides

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.

July 1891

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?

Entire community

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? Yes

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

Children raced

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

A general lunch

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

Sandwiches & cake. Juice

Tea

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?

After dinner till dark
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?  
   What games were played indoors in winter such as card games, etc.?  
   Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children?  
   Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work?  
   Explain.

24. Did children ever meet friends connected with such things as hunting dogs, letter carriers, farmers, or other objects or places in the story described?

**PHOTOS AND GIFTS**

25. What was the date of the first photo that you attended in Saskatchewan?  
   Give year and month if possible.

26. The organized list

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?  
   Explain.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?  
   If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the accommodations at the place you attended (ball games, races, band, children's event)?

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

The Horse racing

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

Changes on new laws

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams? Base Ball team got together and played against a Decker team. What year? 1903 How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.). When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for? 1910 - starting to curling
32. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

33. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School, etc., finally, food and drinks, when held, etc.

34. What changes have you noticed in Picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

35. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

36. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year? 1903

How long did it continue?

37. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, stating date of organization. If possible, and tell something of their activities, played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

38. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

Then was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? 1903
Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic? Replace
Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?
When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 4th).
June

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? —
What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.
School Books

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? When was it begun?
To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?
7.

40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? (Give date.)

Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic?

Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

When was the sports day usually held? (Any month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 4th.)

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball, or other teams?

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?

What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with strangers?

45. Did you buy any books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? When was it begun?

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school texts books as additional reading material?
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? If so:
   When was it started?
   Who started it?
   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material?

Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? If so, when was it started? Is it still in existence? If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library—how many books it contains, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west? Name them.

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped or continued them and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady's Home Journal packages of reading material? Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?
   my father brought the violin from Scotland

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.
   organ $110. Frame $100. Jaws
   new 2 radios

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home-entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

   In the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

   In the community?

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.
   Yes - border songs

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.
   No

63. Was there a band in your community? Yes
   When was it started? 1907
   Who started it? E. Mitchell
   How long did it continue? until 1940
   How many were in it? 86/10
   Who was bandmaster? E. P. Mitchell
   What instruments were included?

   Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
Musical Instruments

56. What musical instruments did you bring with you?
   My family brought a banjo from Georgia.

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

In the community (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the homes?

In the Community

61. Was "folk music," or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or take up work to fit an old tune to a new melody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Has there a band in your community? If so, who started it? When was it started? How long did it continue? Who was conductor? Who was bandmaster? How many were in it? What instruments were included? Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

No

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

Music important
Church in the church

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? 

No
Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

No

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

---

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

---

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearance.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

Hobbies and Special Interests

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? If so, give details of this collection, telling when you started it, why you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned.

(Use back of page, or extra sheet if necessary.)
Oxford
